close_symbols: object table / object-record structure (the structure that stores object names)
object-name buffer size constants used by the object code (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_MAX_NAME_LEN or equivalent)
any helper functions called by OS_ObjectIdGetByName that use <string.h> (e.g. strcmp/strncmp/strcpy/strncpy/strlen/memcpy/memmove/memcmp/strcat/strncat)
explanation:
- OS_CHECK_POINTER: The macro call is used on sem_id and sem_name in the target function; need its definition to confirm it only checks for NULL (and does not perform any string operations or modify the pointer) and to ensure it does not mask or transform sem_name in a way that affects bounds analysis.
- OS_ObjectIdFindByName: This is the immediate callee that receives sem_name. Its implementation is essential to determine whether it calls any <string.h> functions on sem_name (e.g., copying, comparing) and whether those calls are bounded correctly.
- OS_ObjectIdGetByName: Called by OS_ObjectIdFindByName per the call graph. Its implementation will show how object names are compared/handled; it is a likely place for strcmp/strncpy/etc. and thus is necessary to verify no out-of-bounds accesses occur.
- OS_ObjectIdRelease: Called by OS_ObjectIdFindByName; include to see whether any cleanup manipulates name buffers or sem_name in any way relevant to bounds.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: The constant/enum passed to OS_ObjectIdFindByName can select different object tables/behaviors; its value may determine which object-table and name-size constants are used, so it is required to follow the exact code path.
- osal_id_t: The typedef of sem_id is needed to ensure the pointer type and any aliasing/representation that might interact with functions that copy or store name strings (and to confirm no unexpected pointer arithmetic is done).
- object table / object-record structure (the structure that stores object names): To check whether the code copies sem_name into an internal buffer and to know the declared size of that buffer (field type and length) so you can verify copy/compare calls do not exceed bounds.
- object-name buffer size constants used by the object code (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_MAX_NAME_LEN or equivalent): These constants determine the maximum stored name length and are necessary to verify that any strncpy/memcpy/strlen usages are correctly bounded.
- any helper functions called by OS_ObjectIdGetByName that use <string.h> (e.g. strcmp/strncmp/strcpy/strncpy/strlen/memcpy/memmove/memcmp/strcat/strncat): If OS_ObjectIdGetByName (or its callees) invokes these functions, their call sites, argument sizes, and length limits must be inspected to ensure they cannot read/write past sem_name or destination buffers.

In short: the target function itself only forwards sem_name to OS_ObjectIdFindByName, so to determine compliance with the MISRA <string.h> rule you must inspect OS_ObjectIdFindByName and the concrete object-name handling code (data structures, size constants, and any string.h usages) as well as the pointer-check macro and related types/constants that affect which code path and buffer sizes are used.
